module.p: faoileag seagull is a feminine avine derived common noun, with diminutive suffix -(e)ag.

section.p:
The principal parts of faoileag are –
faoileag – nominative singular
faoileig(e) – genitive singular
faoileagan – plural

ul.li:
indefinite
singular
nominative – faoileag
dative – (le) faoileig
genitive – (leabhar) faoileige
plural
nominative – faoileagan
dative – (le) faoileagan
genitive – (leabhraichean) fhaoileag(an)

definite
singular
nominative – an fhaoileag
dative – (leis) an fhaoileig
genitive – (leabhar) na faoileige
plural
nominative – na faoileagan
dative – (leis) na faoileagan
genitive – (leabhraichean) nam faoileag(an)

singular

dative – (le) faoileig
genitive – (leabhar) faoileige
definite
nominative – an fhaoileag
dative – (leis) an fhaoileig
genitive – (leabhar) na faoileige

plural
indefinite
nominative – faoileagan
dative – (le) faoileagan
genitive – (leabhraichean) faoileag(an)
definite
nominative – na faoileagan
dative – (leis) na faoileagan
genitive – (leabhraichean) nam faoileag(an)

nominative
indefinite
singular – faoileag
plural – faoileagan
definite
singular – an fhaoileag
plural – na faoileagan

dative
indefinite

plural – (le) faoileagan
definite

plural – (leis) na faoileagan

genitive
indefinite
singular – (leabhar) faoileige
plural – (leabhraichean) fhaoileag(an)
definite
singular – (leabhar) na faoileige
plural – (leabhraichean) nam faoileag(an)

section.p:
Examples from Gairm –
[...] ’S bha iad ’nan suidhe an sin ag òl uisge-beatha fad na h-oidhch’, na ceathrar aca. An dràsda ’s a rithist shealladh Iain a-mach air an uinneig ris a’ mhuir ’s na h-eileanan. Chitheadh e aig amannan na faoileagan a’ gabhail seachad, ’s chluinneadh e an cuid sgriachail. Le an amhaichean fada caola ’s an cuirp geala biorach mar chlachan bha iad a’ cur gràin’ air. Theab e an glacadh ’s an lìonadh le uisgebeatha, na biasdan nach gabhadh sàsachadh, na clachan aosd ud, na sgòrnanan ud làn gaoith is sgadain. Chaidil e airson greiseag ’s nuair a dhùisg e anns a’ mhadainn bha a bheul salach le blas an uisge-bheatha. Choisich e mach ás a’ bhàta a-measg nam faoileagan, ga[n] sguabadh air falbh le a làmhan, agus lean e air suas an aon rathad a bh’ ann gus an ruigeadh e an tigh. [...]
[...] And they were sat there drinking whisky all night, the four of them. Now and again John would look out the window at the sea and the islands. He could see at times the gulls going past, and he could hear their screeching. With their long thin necks and their pointed white bodies like stones they disgusted him. He almost [??] caught them and filled them with whisky, the beasts that cannot be satiated, those ancient stones, those throats full of wind and herring. He slept for a bit and when he woke up in the morning his mouth was dirty with the taste of the whisky. He walked out of the boat among the gulls, brushing them away with his hands, and he continued up the only road that there was until he reached the house. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
